message.content:
We need to “reconcile” the interest‐receivable balance at period end. In this case the only changes to the Interest Receivable account come from the “Interest Receivables” transactions (which are all recorded as “Unpaid”). One standard way to compute the net change is to add up (or “accrue”) all the individual items. (In many cash‐flow statements this “increase” or “decrease” is computed as the change in the interest receivable balance between the beginning of the period and the end of the period.) 

In our data the beginning balance is not separately given so we assume an opening balance of zero and that the ending (“final”) balance equals the sum of all the “Interest Receivables” amounts. (In our sample problem the “final” item turned out to be a decrease; that was because the sum of the “interest receivable” transactions – which sometimes include negative adjustments – resulted in a net decrease. In our current data all the interest entries are “Unpaid” and are recorded as positive amounts, so the net effect is an “increase”.)

Step‐by‐step we pick out the lines whose “type” is “Interest Receivables” (we list the amounts, rounding as shown):

1. Interest20240101001:   1335.0  
2. Interest20240102002:   1335.0  
3. Interest20240103003:   1246.0  
4. Interest20240104004:   1246.0  
5. Interest20240105005:   1246.0  
6. Interest20240106006:   1068.0  
7. Interest20240107007:   1068.0  
8. Interest20240108008:   801.0  
9. Interest20240109009:   729.8  
10. Interest20240110010:   729.8  
11. Interest20240111011:   729.8  
12. Interest20240112012:   729.8  
13. Interest20240113013:   729.8  
14. Interest20240114014:   729.8  
15. Interest20240115015:   685.3  
16. Interest20240116016:   418.3  
17. Interest20240117017:   418.3  
18. Interest20240118018:   418.3  
19. Interest20240119019:   418.3  
20. Interest20240120020:   418.3  
21. Interest20240121021:   418.3  
22. Interest20240122022:   418.3  
23. Interest20240123023:   418.3  
24. Interest20240124024:   418.3  
25. Interest20240125025:   418.3  
26. Interest20240126026:   275.9  
27. Interest20240127027:   275.9  
28. Interest20240128028:   275.9  
29. Interest20240129029:   275.9  
30. Interest20240130030:   186.9  
31. Interest20240131031:   186.9  
32. Interest20240201032:   97.9  
33. Interest20240202033:   97.9  
34. Interest20240203034:   97.9  
35. Interest20240204035:   97.9  
36. Interest20240205036:   97.9  

Now let’s add them step‐by‐step (we group several similar ones for ease):

• Group 1 (lines 1–2): 1335.0 + 1335.0 = 2670.0  
• Group 2 (lines 3–5): 1246.0 × 3 = 3738.0  
• Group 3 (lines 6–7): 1068.0 × 2 = 2136.0  
• Group 4 (line 8):    801.0  
• Group 5 (lines 9–14): 729.8 × 6 = 4378.8  
• Group 6 (line 15):    685.3  
• Group 7 (lines 16–25): There are 10 entries at 418.3 each → 10 × 418.3 = 4183.0  
• Group 8 (lines 26–29): 275.9 × 4 = 1103.6  
• Group 9 (lines 30–31): 186.9 × 2 = 373.8  
• Group 10 (lines 32–36): 97.9 × 5 = 489.5  

Now add all groups sequentially:  
2670.0 + 3738.0 = 6408.0  
6408.0 + 2136.0 = 8544.0  
8544.0 + 801.0 = 9345.0  
9345.0 + 4378.8 = 13723.8  
13723.8 + 685.3 = 14409.1  
14409.1 + 4183.0 = 18592.1  
18592.1 + 1103.6 = 19695.7  
19695.7 + 373.8 = 20069.5  
20069.5 + 489.5 = 20559.0  

Thus the ending (or “final”) balance change in Interest Receivable is +20,559.0. In the cash‐flow statement this would be reported as an “increase” (that is, a use of cash when reconciling operating cash flows). 

So our final answer is:

{
  "(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable": "20559.0"
}

Below is the answer in the required JSON format.
